name: NPR
text:
New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s new executive order allows businesses to refuse entrance to anyone not wearing a face mask.

"People don't have a right to jeopardize other people's health," Cuomo tweeted.
https://t.co/PTjxXgZTLM

name: NPR
text: A purely economic analysis of coronavirus risks that frontline workers face suggests that hazard pay should be closer to $10 or $20 more an hour, according to calculations by a Columbia University economist. https://t.co/ysR7IMbrf9

name: NPR
text:
School leaders are warning of a financial meltdown that could devastate many districts — and set back an entire generation of students.

"We're about to see a school funding crisis unlike anything we have ever seen in modern history," one expert says.
 
https://t.co/4gI52s9wpP

name: NPR
text: NASA astronauts are heading to space from U.S. soil for the first time in nine years aboard SpaceX's Dragon capsule. https://t.co/3mAR2cmSQJ

name: NPR
text:
ICYMI: Sen. Mitch McConnell says the next coronavirus response bill will be the "final" — and that he won't support extending the $600 in federal unemployment benefits that run out at the end of July.
https://t.co/oDXyLvGP94

name: NPR
text:
Many people with dementia who fall ill can’t express their symptoms, and early coronavirus markers may look similar to their other pre-existing conditions.

That means COVID-19 can go undiagnosed in the early stages. @hereandnow https://t.co/cRuonGCVlP

name: NPR
text:
Michael Ortiz had already spent a year and a half working toward his goal of 100 100-mile races in 100 weeks. He’d be sad to see it end because he was supposed to stay inside.

"But there is a solution. ... Running 13,200 loops of your living room."
 https://t.co/zrXIVMPBDO

name: NPR
text:
Jordan has the site where Jesus was baptized — but Israel manages to attract more tourists to a rival site on the western side of the Jordan River. 

Jordan is looking to change that. https://t.co/Ei92Dx4HSb

name: NPR
text: At a time when voters are increasingly turning toward mail-in voting, the U.S. Postal Service is facing significant challenges — including ridicule from the president, financial woes and new management. https://t.co/mvi9OR0iXc

name: NPR
text:
This 85-year-old and her husband have updated their will. Now, they're working on a living will. 

"I had never thought that I would want to write down 'Do not ventilate,'" she said. "There are other people who need them more, and I have had a good life." 
https://t.co/beEMuMUHew

name: NPR
text: "If we do have the courage to move to a more realistic, hopeful view of human nature, then we can move to a very different kind of society as well," author Rutger Bregman says. "It's actually quite revolutionary." https://t.co/WtDkJbt3dg
